descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Richard Hamilton scored 33 points Thursday night, and Michael Jordan had 25 as the Washington Wizards sailed into the All-Star break with their biggest surprise yet, a 108-101 victory over the Sacramento Kings.
article.headline: Hamilton, Jordan combine for 58 Wizards points

images.name: Hamilton, Richard 020207 inline
images.caption: Richard Hamilton lets fly with a shot on the way to his game-high 33 points.

article.linkText: Wizards beat Kings in their biggest stunner so far
article.story:
WASHINGTON (AP) -- Michael Jordan said this week that Popeye Jones "could take my place in the All-Star game." Jones certainly put up All-Star numbers Thursday night -- against the team with the best record in the league. Jones survived foul trouble, made all eight of his shots from the field -- including his first dunk of the season -- and finished with 18 points and 15 rebounds as the Washington Wizards sailed into the All-Star break with their biggest surprise yet, a 108-101 victory over the Sacramento Kings. "Popeye is our unsung hero," coach Doug Collins said. "We know who he is. Every night he battles bigger, stronger, quicker guys. "But the games aren't played on paper. They are played on the court. A long time ago, a friend told me you never gauge a horse's speed with a watch; you gauge it with a race. And that's what competition does, it brings out either the best in people or the worst. And, Popeye, it brings out the best in him." Jones' eighth double-double of the season, along with his defensive job on Chris Webber and Vlade Divac, combined with Richard Hamilton's 33 points and Jordan's 25 to put the Wizards five games above .500 -- their best record at the All-Star break in 23 years. They have won five straight and seven of eight, and their 26-21 record is a 14-win improvement over 12-35 after 47 games a year ago. "This is the type of emotion I always envisioned about this team," Jordan said, "where the young guys just feed off each other. I told everybody before the game: 'We've got nothing to lose. Everybody expects us to lose by 25 anyway, so just go out there and have fun and play hard.' " Jordan, who has been nicknamed Tonto to Hamilton's Lone Ranger, made 12 of 30 shots and had nine assists and six rebounds in 41 minutes. "Tonto and the Lone Ranger's back, you know," Jordan said. "The Lone Ranger was there, and Tonto was right behind him, and we were able to just nullify their scores. Popeye played with what he could give us, and we were able to plug this one out." The Kings came out flat at the end of a four-game road trip, having traveled overnight after a victory at Boston the night before. Webber returned to the lineup after missing the Celtics game with the stomach flu. Still, Sacramento had the energy to rally from 15 down to tie the game in the third quarter. Much of the game was played at the Kings' preferred uptempo style. All five starters scored in double figures, but neither Webber (9-for-21) nor Peja Stojakovic (6-for-16) shot well. "We just didn't defend them well all night long," coach Rick Adelman said. "We got beat by the same play time after time. We didn't rebound the ball well. And when they finally missed, we didn't get the ball back." Then there was that unsung hero Jones. "I don't expect him to do that much damage," Adelman said. Webber, who had been 5-0 against the Wizards since they traded him to the Kings in 1998, finished with 21 points and nine rebounds. Stojakovic scored 16 points. The Wizards shot 60 percent in the first quarter. Jordan and Hamilton were a formidable 1-2 punch, with Jordan's three-point play starting a 10-0 run that put Washington ahead 27-16. The Wizards kept the lead between nine and 15 in the second quarter, keeping pace even when the Kings sped up the tempo. Jones did most of his damage in the second half. He played all 24 minutes, and was savvy enough to go 16 minutes between his fourth and fifth foul. "It's been long overdue," said Jones, who has played with five teams since he was drafted in 1992, "with all the injuries I've been through over the years. I'm finally healthy, and when I'm healthy I've always been able to contribute." The Kings came back and took their only lead of the second half, 63-61, on Mike Bibby's 3-pointer with 7:04 to go in the third quarter. The Wizards didn't fold, however, and Jordan answered with a baseline fadeaway and Jones followed with a 16-footer to swing the momentum back to Washington. A 24-7 run at the end of the third quarter put the Wizards in control, and they led by as many as 19 in the fourth. "I think with all due respect to them, we caught them on a good night," Jones said. "They may have been a little tired, but we played excellent."

Game notes
Jordan crumbled to the court in pain after banging knees with teammate Eton Thomas early in the second quarter. Jordan got up after a few seconds and remained in the game. ... There's definitely something going around: Washington's Jahidi White missed the game with a virus, and teammate Hubert Davis missed his fifth straight game with the flu. Rookie Brendan Haywood made his second career start in place of White and had 11 rebounds. ... The Wizards scored a season-high 35 points in the first quarter.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
